human_expected_interpretation: Minsu met Younghee. Minsu went home.

mt_outputs.papago: Minsu met Younghee. He went home.
mt_outputs.google: Minsu met Younghee and went home.

analysis_note: Outputs align with the human reading; Google may avoid explicit pronoun resolution via restructuring.

human_expected_interpretation: Cheolsu called his younger sibling. The younger sibling arrived late.

mt_outputs.papago: Cheolsu called his brother. He arrived late.
mt_outputs.google: Cheolsu called his younger brother. He arrived late.

analysis_note: MT defaults to previous grammatical subject, ignoring event-structure reasoning.

human_expected_interpretation: (Someone) bought an umbrella because it was raining.

mt_outputs.papago: I bought an umbrella because it rained.
mt_outputs.google: It rained, so I bought an umbrella.

analysis_note: Systems introduce a first-person subject not specified in Korean.

human_expected_interpretation: (Someone) called, but (that same person) didn’t answer.

mt_outputs.papago: I called, but he didn't answer.
mt_outputs.google: I called but you didn't answer.

analysis_note: Systems introduce multiple discourse participants without support from the source.

human_expected_interpretation: (Someone) met the boss yesterday. The boss spoke.

mt_outputs.papago: I met the boss yesterday. He told me.
mt_outputs.google: I met the boss yesterday. He said:

analysis_note: Outputs look plausible but do not show explicit sensitivity to honorific constraints guiding human inference.

mt_outputs.papago: The teacher came. He told me to sit down.
mt_outputs.google: The teacher came and told us to sit down.

analysis_note: Systems add recipients (me/us) and don’t transparently encode honorific-based reasoning.

human_expected_interpretation: Minsu went to the meeting. Someone of higher status spoke.

mt_outputs.papago: Minsu went to the meeting. He said.
mt_outputs.google: Minsu went to the meeting. He said.

analysis_note: When cues conflict, systems default to grammatical continuity over honorific restriction.

human_expected_interpretation: Ambiguous: either the speaker helped the friend or the friend helped the speaker (context-dependent).

mt_outputs.papago: I met my friend yesterday. I helped her.
mt_outputs.google: I met a friend yesterday. He helped me.

analysis_note: Systems cannot preserve Korean ambiguity and commit to different referents without cues.
